owl:Ontology.dc:creator: Carlo Teo Pedretti
Francesca Mangialardo
Mattia Spadoni
owl:Ontology.terms:title: CoSMO - Calvino's Six Memos Ontology
owl:Ontology.core:Rights: This work is distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/).
owl:Ontology.rdfs:comment: CoSMO (Calvino's Six Memos Ontology) is a literary criticism based ontology that expresses in a formal way the concept behind Calvino's textual interpretation.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a rhetorical figure to an interpreted concept. E.g. a period that expresses mutability could be constructed using anaphora.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: denotes

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates an interpreted concept to a fictional character that represents it.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has embodiment

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a literary text with a fictional character that is mentioned inside the narrative of that text
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has fictional character

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a text with an interpreted concept recognised by Calvino's as a value or virtue of literature.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has literary value

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a literary text that contains a rhetorical figure.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has rhetorical figure

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a fictional character or interpretation to the text where it comes from.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has source

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property states that heaviness is absence of lightness.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is absence of

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property shows when lightness is absent from a particular literary text.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is absent from

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates an interpreted concept to a rhetorical figure.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is denoted by

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relates a fictional character to the interpreted concept that it symbolizes
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is embodiment of

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a fictional character that is present in a particular literary text.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is fictional character in

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property describes the relation between heaviness and mutability since the latter is what changes heaviness into lightness.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is lightened by

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates an interpreted concept recognised by Calvino's as a value or virtue of literature with a particular literary text.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is literary value in

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property states the opposition between heaviness and lightness
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is opposite of

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a particular literary text with a fictional character that is present in it.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is source

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property states that lightness is related to heaviness because of a subtraction of weight.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is subtraction of

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a rhetorical figure with a particular literary text in which it is present.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is used in

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property relates a literary text with lightness through a connection stating that the text lacks of lightness
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: lacks of

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: This property indicates the lightening force of mutability upon the category of heaviness.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: lightens

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: A name given to the resource
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: Title

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Relates a rhetorical figure to a specific line of the textual reference
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: is located in line

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Relates a concept or agent to a fragment that includes their textual string reference
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: has textual part

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Relates a concept or agent to a text that includes their textual string reference
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: has textual representation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Absence of light
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Darkness

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The inability to act as expressed in literary texts
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Inertia

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A lack of physical or literary motion as represented in literary texts
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Stillness

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A resource that acts or has the power to act
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Agent

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The visual luminosity expressed in a literary text
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Brightness

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An abstract idea or notion
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Concept

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Quality of things that have nature, aspect, appearence of fine dust and are therefore discontinuous and fragmentary.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Dustiness

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Quality of things that are put on the same level
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Equality

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A realization of a single work usually in a physical form.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Expression

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An imaginary person represented in a work of literary fiction
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Fictional character

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A concept to represent the weight, the inertia, the opacity of the world and the writing
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Heaviness

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Identity refers to when a figure uses two or more identical elements. e.g., Ploce: O villain, villain, smiling, damned villain!(Hamlet [5]).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Identity

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: This class defines the concepts involved when interpreting a literary text
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Interpretation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A concept that results from interpreting a literary text
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Interpreted concept

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Literary value or virtue of a literary text reached by removing weight from the structure of stories and from language.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Lightness

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A textual expression of a work of literature
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Literary text

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A movement from a place or location to another in literary texts
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Movement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Quality of everything that can be transformed into something else
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Mutability

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Omission refers to when a figure omits expected elements. e.g., Asyndeton (which omits the expected conjunction, “and”): I came, I saw, I conquered.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Omission

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Opposition refers to when a figure oppose two structures or concepts. e.g., Oxymoron: A wanton modesty. Proud humility.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Opposition

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A living or dead individual
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Person

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Repetition refers to when a figure uses repetition of sounds (consonants, vowels, or syllables), words, syntax (phrases or clauses) or semantics (concepts). e.g., Rhyme–Hickory Dickory Dock. The mouse ran up the clock.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Repetition

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of some common strategies employed by rhetorical figures
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Rhetorical figure

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Series refers to when a figure establishes a series (through words or concepts). e.g., Abecedarian: Adorable, beautiful, charming, delightful, exciting, fantastic–you run the gamut from A to Z [1].
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Series

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Similarity (partial-identity) refers to when a figure uses resemblance of a concept. e.g., Simile: My love is like a red, red rose.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Similarity

owl:NamedIndividual.textualPart: Movesi il vecchierel canut e bianco
ha un suono, e il mirto/altro suono, e il ginepro/altro ancóra, stromenti/diversi
chi sa dove, chi sa dove!
Piove su i nostri[...]/Piove su le nostre[...]
E andiam di fratta in fratta,/or congiunti or disciolti
No Bone had He to bind Him
le tue chiome/auliscono come/le chiare ginestre
il cuor nel petto è come pesca/intatta,
i denti negli alvèoli/con come mandorle acerbe.
seguendo ‘l desio,/per mirar la sembianza di colui/ch’ancor lassú nel ciel vedere spera:
E sei come le voci/della terra

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:creator: http://viaf.org/viaf/39382430
owl:NamedIndividual.dc:title: Movesi il vecchierel canuto e bianco
owl:NamedIndividual.textualReference: Movesi il vecchierel canuto e bianco del dolce loco ov’ha sua età fornita e da la famigliuola sbigottita che vede il caro padre venir manco; indi traendo poi l’antiquo fianco per l’estreme giornate di sua vita, quanto piú pò, col buon voler s’aita, rotto dagli anni, e dal cammino stanco ; e viene a Roma, seguendo ‘l desio, per mirar la sembianza di colui ch’ancor lassú nel ciel vedere spera : cosí, lasso, talor vo cerchand’io, donna, quanto è possibile, in altrui la disïata vostra forma vera.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:creator: http://viaf.org/viaf/49220129
owl:NamedIndividual.dc:title: La pioggia nel pineto
owl:NamedIndividual.textualReference:
Taci. Su le soglie del bosco non odo parole che dici umane; ma odo parole più nuove che parlano gocciole e foglie lontane. Ascolta. Piove dalle nuvole sparse . Piove su le tamerici salmastre ed arse, piove su i pini scagliosi ed irti, piove su i mirti divini, su le ginestre fulgenti di fiori accolti, su i ginepri folti di coccole aulenti, piove su i nostri volti silvani , piove su le nostre mani ignude, su i nostri vestimenti leggieri, su i freschi pensieri che l'anima schiude novella, su la favola bella che ieri t'illuse , che oggi m'illude , o Ermione.
Odi? La pioggia cade su la solitaria verdura con un crepitío che dura e varia nell'aria secondo le fronde più rade, men rade. Ascolta. Risponde al pianto il canto delle cicale che il pianto australe non impaura, nè il ciel cinerino. E il pino ha un suono, e il mirto altro suono, e il ginepro altro ancóra, stromenti diversi sotto innumerevoli dita . E immersi noi siam nello spirto silvestre , d'arborea vita viventi; e il tuo volto ebro è molle di pioggia come una foglia , e le tue chiome auliscono come le chiare ginestre , o creatura terrestre che hai nome Ermione.
Ascolta, ascolta . L'accordo delle aeree cicale a poco a poco più sordo si fa sotto il pianto che cresce; ma un canto vi si mesce più roco che di laggiù sale , dall'umida ombra remota. Più sordo e più fioco s'allenta, si spegne . Sola una nota ancor trema, si spegne , risorge, trema, si spegne. Non s'ode voce del mare. Or s'ode su tutta la fronda crosciare l'argentea pioggia che monda, il croscio che varia secondo la fronda più folta, men folta. Ascolta. La figlia dell'aria è muta; ma la figlia del limo lontana, la rana, canta nell'ombra più fonda , chi sa dove, chi sa dove! E piove su le tue ciglia, Ermione.
Piove su le tue ciglia nere sìche par tu pianga ma di piacere; non bianca ma quasi fatta virente, par da scorza tu esca. E tutta la vita è in noi fresca aulente, il cuor nel petto è come pesca intatta , tra le pàlpebre gli occhi son come polle tra l'erbe , i denti negli alvèoli con come mandorle acerbe . E andiam di fratta in fratta, or congiunti or disciolti (e il verde vigor rude ci allaccia i mallèoli c'intrica i ginocchi) chi sa dove, chi sa dove! E piove su i nostri vólti silvani , piove su le nostre mani ignude, su i nostri vestimenti leggieri, su i freschi pensieri che l'anima schiude novella, su la favola bella che ieri m'illuse, che oggi t'illude, o Ermione.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:creator: http://viaf.org/viaf/36922880
owl:NamedIndividual.dc:title: senza titolo
owl:NamedIndividual.textualReference: Hai viso di pietra scolpita, sangue di terra dura, sei venuta dal mare. Tutto accogli e scruti e respingi da te come il mare. Nel cuore hai silenzio, hai parole inghiottite. Sei buia. Per te l’alba è silenzio. E sei come le voci della terra – l’urto della secchia nel pozzo, la canzone del fuoco, il tonfo di una mela; le parole rassegnate e cupe sulle soglie, il grido del bimbo – le cose che non passano mai. Tu non muti. Sei buia, sei la cantina chiusa, dal battuto di terra, dov’è entrato una volta ch’era scalzo il bambino, e ci ripensa sempre. Sei la camera buia cui si ripensa sempre, come al cortile antico dove s’apriva l’alba.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:creator: http://viaf.org/viaf/31995584
owl:NamedIndividual.dc:title: senza titolo
owl:NamedIndividual.textualReference:
The Wind – tapped like a tired Man – And like a Host – “Come in” I boldly answered – entered then My Residence within
A Rapid – footless Guest – To offer whom a Chair Were as impossible as hand A Sofa to the Air – No Bone had He to bind Him – His Speech was like the Push Of numerous Humming Birds at once From a superior Bush –
His Countenance – a Billow – His Fingers, as He passed
Let go a music – as of tunes Blown tremulous in Glass –
He visited – still flitting – Then like a timid Man Again, He tapped – 'twas flurriedly – And I became alone –

owl:NamedIndividual.textualPart: His Countenance – a Billow –/His Fingers, as He passed
è molle di pioggia/come una foglia
tra le pàlpebre gli occhi/son come polle tra l'erbe,
pietra scolpita/e sangue di terra dura
la canzone del fuoco,/il tonfo di una mela;/le parole rassegnate/e cupe sulle soglie,/il grido del bimbo – le cose
He visited – still flitting Then like a timid Man/Again, He tapped
è molle di pioggia/come una foglia
And like a Host – “Come in”/I boldly answered –
His Speech was like the Push
i denti negli alvèoli/con come mandorle acerbe.
tra le pàlpebre gli occhi/son come polle tra l'erbe,
il cuor nel petto è come pesca/intatta,
tue chiome auliscono come le chiare ginestre

owl:NamedIndividual.textualReference: Più sordo e più fioco/s'allenta, si spegne

owl:NamedIndividual.textualPart: The Wind tapped like a tired Man/[...]Then like a timid Man/Again, He tapped

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: An entity primarily responsible for making the resource.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Creator

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Symmetry refers to when a figure pairs two constructions in an inverse (“mirrored”) way. e.g. Antimetabole: When the going gets tough, the tough get going.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: symmetry
